case_vignette: A 93-year-old woman is brought to the physician because of a purple area on her right arm that has been growing for one month! She has not had any pain or itching of the area! She has hyperlipidemia, a history of basal cell carcinoma treated with Mohs surgery 2 years ago, and a history of invasive ductal carcinoma of the right breast treated with radical mastectomy 57 years ago! She has had chronic lymphedema of the right upper extremity since the mastectomy! Her only medication is simvastatin! She lives in an assisted living facility! She is content with her living arrangement but feels guilty that she is dependent on others! Vital signs are within normal limits! Physical examination shows extensive edema of the right arm! Skin exam of the proximal upper right extremity shows three coalescing, 0!5–1!0 cm heterogeneous, purple-colored plaques with associated ulceration!
question: Which  is the most likely diagnosis?

trial_0.vignette_frq: Angiosarcoma associated with chronic lymphedema (Stewart-Treves syndrome)

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Dermatology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask only one question at a time, and it should not be more than 1 line. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. Do not ask the same question multiple times. Ask different questions to cover more information. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain, only give the diagnosis name. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized. You must give only 1 diagnosis otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I have a purple area on my right arm that has been growing for one month.
Has the purple area caused any pain, itching, or burning sensations?
No, I have not had any pain or itching in the area.
Have you noticed any other skin changes or symptoms elsewhere on your body?
No, I have not noticed any other skin changes or symptoms elsewhere on my body.
Do you have any personal or family history of skin disorders or other medical conditions?
Yes, I have a history of basal cell carcinoma that was treated with Mohs surgery 2 years ago, and I also have a history of breast cancer treated with a mastectomy 57 years ago.
Are you currently taking any medications, or have you recently started any new medications?
I am only taking simvastatin.
Is there any history of similar lesions in the family or is this the first occurrence?
This is the first occurrence; there is no family history of similar lesions.
Final Diagnosis: Kaposi Sarcoma

trial_0.summarized_conversation: A patient reports a growing purple area on their right arm that has been present for one month. They have not experienced any pain or itching in the area, nor have they noticed any other skin changes or symptoms elsewhere on their body. The patient has a medical history of basal cell carcinoma treated with Mohs surgery 2 years ago and a history of breast cancer treated with a mastectomy 57 years ago. Currently, the patient is only taking simvastatin. This is the first occurrence of such a lesion, and there is no family history of similar lesions.
